subject: Re: [junit] Failing multiple times in one test
msgSnippet: Having multiple failures per test allows me to provide much more detailed reports.  In my environment, running each test is very expensive, so I want to get
messageBody:
Having multiple failures per test allows me to provide much more
detailed reports. In my environment, running each test is very
expensive, so I want to get the most out of it as possible. If the
assertion failure means the rest of my assertions aren't run, I'm
missing a lot of information. Initially, I broke them all up into
separate tests, but that proved to be clumsy, so I modified the code to
allow for multiple failures (basically, a failed assertion wouldn't
throw an exception, it would simply be added to the TestResults
failures), and writing the tests proved much easier and provided much
more information than previously available.

-shane

On Monday, September 3, 2001, at 12:14 PM, Laurent Duperval wrote:

> On 1 Sep, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>>> I'm writing a test whose purpose is to make sure that a Hashtable
>>> contains a
>>> certain set of keys. Basically, the test will make sure that someone
>>> filling
>>> out a form on the web provides all the mandatory info
>>
>> Hashtable? Tsk, tsk... why aren't you using Map instead? :)
>>
>
> Uhm... What's the diff?
>
>>> I'd like a way to make
>>> the test fail for every parameter that is missing and consider each
>>> of the
>>> iterations as one test.
>>
>> Silly question: why? Does it matter whether one, two or ten parameters
>> are
>> not handled correctly? I think it matters more whether they are all
>> handled correctly, or not.
>>
>
> It does but the fact that one parameter fails may have nothing to do
> with
> the fact that another fails since validation may be occuring in
> different
> parts of the code. By failing once per invalid parameter, you are
> immediately pointed to the proper place to debug. And if the test lists
> all
> the parameters that failed, a developer could possibly see a pattern,
> which
> also helps in debugging.
>
>> Also, who cares how many tests there are? Do you? Your manager? I don't
>> want to get into the discussion again about counting tests, but I have
>> never really cared how many tests I have, as long as I'm happy with the
>> quality of the tests.
>>
>
> No, counting tests wasn't the motive behind my question.
>
>> Since JUnit counts test methods by default, you'd need one method per
>> parameter. Do you really think that's a useful thing to do? I don't.
>>
>
> No, that's why I asked if there was a better method than what I'm doing
> now:
> I have a StringBuffer to which I add all the parameters that failed and
> then
> use the StringBuffer in fail().
>
> L
